children.value: Accept terms and condition on Docker registry:
click on database > enterprise > accept t&c

props.code:
SQL> alter session set "_ORACLE_SCRIPT"=true;

Session altered.

children.value:
SQL> alter session set "_ORACLE_SCRIPT"=true;

Session altered.

props.code:
SQL> create user aryan identified by aryan;

User created.

children.value:
SQL> create user aryan identified by aryan;

User created.
Grant all preveleges to that user

props.code:
SQL> GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES TO aryan;

Grant succeeded.

children.value:
SQL> GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES TO aryan;

Grant succeeded.
Now that you are connect with user aryan with password aryan. You can create a table

props.code:
SQL> CREATE TABLE publisher
  2  (
  3  "id_publisher" NUMBER(3, 0) NOT NULL ENABLE,
  4  "name" VARCHAR2(200 byte) NOT NULL ENABLE,
  5  CONSTRAINT "PUBLISHER_PK" PRIMARY KEY ("id_publisher")
  6  );

Table created.

children.value:
SQL> CREATE TABLE publisher
  2  (
  3  "id_publisher" NUMBER(3, 0) NOT NULL ENABLE,
  4  "name" VARCHAR2(200 byte) NOT NULL ENABLE,
  5  CONSTRAINT "PUBLISHER_PK" PRIMARY KEY ("id_publisher")
  6  );

Table created.
See what tables are accessible to aryan user

props.code:
SQL> SELECT table_name FROM user_tables;

TABLE_NAME
------------------------------------------------------------
PUBLISHER

children.value:
SQL> SELECT table_name FROM user_tables;

props.code:
SQL> INSERT INTO publisher ("id_publisher", "name") VALUES (2, 'Another Publisher');

1 row created.

children.value:
SQL> INSERT INTO publisher ("id_publisher", "name") VALUES (2, 'Another Publisher');

1 row created.
Updated the record on second ID

props.code:
SQL> UPDATE publisher SET "name" = 'novo nome da editora' WHERE "id_publisher" = 2;

1 row updated.
